title: Herb Kaplow
text:
Herbert Elias Kaplow (February 2, 1927 – July 27, 2013) was an American <a href="News%20broadcasting%23Network%20news%20programming">television news</a> <a href="correspondent">correspondent</a>. His main focus was reporting out of <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, covering <a href="Political%20campaign">presidential campaigns</a> and those who were elected.
Early years.
Kaplow was born in 1927 in <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> to <a href="Jewish%20Americans">Jewish immigrants from Europe</a>. He was raised in <a href="Queens">Queens</a> and attended <a href="Queens%20College%2C%20City%20University%20of%20New%20York">Queens College</a>, before being <a href="Conscription%20in%20the%20United%20States">drafted</a> into the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>. He was later assigned to the <a href="American%20Forces%20Network%23History">Armed Forces Radio Service</a>, where he read scripts covering the <a href="Nuremberg%20Trials">Nuremberg Trials</a> as well as covered a <a href="The%20Championships%2C%20Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> tennis championship. After his military discharge, he returned to get a degree in history at Queens College. He went on to earn a master's degree from the <a href="Medill%20School%20of%20Journalism">Medill School of Journalism</a> at <a href="Northwestern%20University">Northwestern University</a>, after a two-year radio announcer job at <a href="WCTC">WCTC</a> in <a href="New%20Brunswick%2C%20New%20Jersey">New Brunswick, New Jersey</a>.
National news career.
After obtaining his degree, he moved to Washington, D.C., to work for <a href="NBC%20Red%20Network">NBC</a>'s radio <a href="Network%20affiliate">affiliate</a> <a href="WRC-TV">WRC</a>, before taking an editing job on the network's "News of the World" program. A few years later, he became an NBC news correspondent for radio and television. In 1968, he became a <a href="White%20House%20press%20corps%23Former%20White%20House%20correspondents">White House correspondent</a>. In 1972, he switched to <a href="ABC%20News">ABC News</a>, where he remained until his retirement in 1994.
Notable news stories.
During his four decades of covering news stories, which included 10 presidential campaigns and 19 <a href="Presidential%20nominating%20convention">nominating conventions</a>, Kaplow also reported on major events of the <a href="civil%20rights%20movement">civil rights movement</a> from the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. Supreme Court</a>'s 1954 "<a href="Brown%20v.%20Board%20of%20Education">Brown v. Board of Education</a>" ruling to <a href="Desegregation">desegregate schools</a> to the <a href="Freedom%20Riders">Freedom Riders</a>'s struggle to integrate buses in the early 1960s. Kaplow also covered <a href="NASA">NASA</a>'s <a href="Project%20Mercury">Project Mercury</a>.
He covered the <a href="Cuban%20Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a> that culminated in the victory of <a href="Communism">communists</a> led by <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Fidel Castro</a> in 1959. After the failed 1961 <a href="Bay%20of%20Pigs%20Invasion">Bay of Pigs Invasion</a> of Cuba by American-backed Cuban exiles, Kaplow was the first American reporter to interview Castro.
Kaplow also covered <a href="Richard%20Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> from 1958 to 1968. This kept Nixon in the public eye, which historian <a href="Erik%20Barnouw">Erik Barnouw</a> believed helped Nixon win the <a href="Republican%20Party%20presidential%20primaries%2C%201968">1968 presidential nomination</a>.
Personal life.
After retiring in 1994, Kaplow lived in <a href="Falls%20Church%2C%20Virginia">Falls Church, Virginia</a>, with his wife, Betty. They had three sons: Steven, Bobby and Larry. Herb spent an undisclosed amount of time in an assisted living facility, battling <a href="dementia">dementia</a>, which affected his ability to speak. He died on July 27, 2013, from a <a href="stroke">stroke</a> in <a href="Arlington%20County%2C%20Virginia">Arlington, Virginia</a>, at the age of 86.
